text: It's a nutty idea, right? (And speaking of lack of transparency...) But... maybe. With the house, I'm probably going to get most of the money back and may even make a fair bit. But I don't get to sell the degree, not directly. Grrrr.
author: ronlieber

text: Good day @WSJopinion! Why do you so rarely cite the journalism you mention in the ledes to your editorials by publication of origin, let alone link to it? It's just so churlish. "Screw you, reader! Google it!" Here's that link for you. You're welcome! https://www.politico.com/states/new-york/albany/story/2019/03/06/real-estate-launched-trump-it-also-could-hurt-him-in-2020-897459 …
author: ronlieber

text: So many of these stories recently, all citing same studies/limited outcomes data. Not reporters' fault. Blame colleges for giving us little to make these $300,000 decisions on. I'll have more to say & more criteria to consider in "What to Pay for College."
author: ronlieber

text: Does the medical system report to the NYT bestseller list? Totally going to try something like this!
author: ronlieber

text: To me, there are few joys in journalism greater than coming up with a great story idea. In 2004, I set out to answer a ?: How do you get thousands of athletes, mascots and tuba players to the NCAA tournament in 48 hours flat? I found out in Iowa:  https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB107957156909358713 … #AvGeek
author: ronlieber

text: Can't wait to read this.
author: ronlieber

text: These are arguably the most exciting 4 days in sports. Yet every year, there are enormous numbers of empty seats the first two days. I understand why it happens I think -- each ticket is good for 2 games and people skip one? But there must be a better way. What? I want to go!
author: ronlieber

text: Today’s White House executive order will make loan debt/earnings available broken down by major/program, as I pleaded for in this column. Anyone want make the case that it’s a bad idea?
author: ronlieber

text: Yup. See also the @pameladruck oped on this point from several weeks ago.

text: Yes, Vanguard too. You have to -- HAVE TO -- keep an eye on the accounts of your sick and dead relatives and close friends. This happens more than you think, though hopefully not that much at Vanguard.

text: Both -- plus, I think, the real fear of the fact that there's now a better than even chance of literally falling through the social class floor, of not doing as well as your parents did. And most parents who read the NYT have done pretty well. So...

text: @JetBlue Love that LGA/MAT has a water fountain with a bottle fillup spigot. Maybe we could do that at JFK one of these years? But I could do without the piercing alarm every 15 minutes. Does anyone know how to turn it off? Thanks!

text: Your regular reminder that @DeanJulie can coin a phrase and how. “The point is to prepare the kid for the road, instead of preparing the road for the kid.” We should make bumper stickers with this & slap them on cars stuck in traffic on the 101 & the 280.
author: ronlieber

text: Let me guess -- your right answer is don't go to Muhlenberg for a penny more than what Penn State would cost?!

text: Much respect to the people who still have the chutzpah to send me notes seeking help and then make me fill out an Earthlink (Earthlink!!) spam form to have my reply go through. For some reason, I always do it.

text: I BELIEVE IN SAUCIER PARENTING “One didn’t like to eat food with sauce. Her whole life, her parents had helped her avoid sauce, calling friends before going to their houses for dinner. At college, she didn’t know how to cope with the cafeteria options — covered in sauce.”
